awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Fundamental limits and coding for massive wireless random-access
awd_abstract_narration:
The key expected innovation of the next generation of radio-access networks (such as cellular) is their ability to service vast numbers of active devices as envisioned in the so-called "Internet-of-Things". Unfortunately, current networks were designed with the human-type communication in mind, and this led to a focus on the operating regime of a (relatively) few simultaneously active users. More specifically, present systems employ centralized resource allocation, thus orthogonalizing the access from different users. This solution is not acceptable for machine-type communication, as it relies on a significant control-layer overhead thereby incurring a significant penalty in latency and energy efficiency. Consequently, there is a strong economical demand for a new solution in both the unlicensed spectrum (so called, low-power wide-area networks) and the licensed spectrum (5G).

The goal of this work is to provide theoretical guidance for the design of the multiple-access layer in the next generation of wireless networks. Classical work on the topic lacks several specific details, making it inadequate: ignoring the control-layer overhead in network analytic literature, and ignoring delay in information theory. Consequently, this work aims to provide necessary contemporary modifications: (a) a gigantic number of idle (inactive) users; (b) a still large number of active users; (c) short packets; (d) high energy-efficiency (low energy-per-bit). This project introduces a new paradigm of random-access coding that separates data communication from user identification, for which fundamental limits are going to be derived and the low-complexity practical solutions studied. Performance of the currently available solutions will be contrasted with the non-asymptotic fundamental limits and new solutions developed. In addition to information-theoretic and communication-theoretic parts, the work involves a combinatorial-theoretic component in the form of constructing Sidon sets, B2-sequences and superimposed codes.

por.por_cntn:
This project started at the time when two new wireless communication technologies were being developed: the low-power wide-area networks (LP-WANs) in the unlicensed spectrum and the 5G in the licensed (cellular) spectrum. Both technologies targeted the rapidly expanding sector of the so-called IoT (for ?Internet-of-Things?) devices, which typically represent autonomous data- collecting sensors and simple remote-controlled actuators. Indeed, the number of such devices over the time-span of this project tripled (from about 5 billion to about 15 billion, worldwide).

Unfortunately, evolving the current radio-access networks (RANs) to address this growth is not just a matter of scaling up the capacity, since previous generation RANs were designed with the human-type communication in mind. This type of communication focuses on the regime of a (relatively) few simultaneously active users, which, however, when active consume a large amount of bandwidth. More specifically, those older systems employed centralized resource allocation, orthogonalizing the access from different users. This kind of solution is not acceptable for machine- type communication, as it relies on a significant control-layer overhead thereby incurring a significant penalty in latency and energy efficiency. Consequently, there was a strong economical demand for a new solution, which was precisely the basis of this grant proposal.

This project paved a way for theoretical understanding of the design of the multiple-access layer in the next generation of RANs. Classical work on the topic lacked several specific details, making it inadequate: ignoring the control-layer overhead in network analytic literature, and ignoring de- lay/latency in information theory one. This proposal provided an innovative framework addressing all the key contemporary roadblocks: (a) a gigantic number of idle (inactive) users; (b) a still large number of active users; (c) short packets; (d) focus on high energy-efficiency (low energy-per-bit).

The main novelty of this work was introduction of a new paradigm of random-access coding that separates data communication from user identification. This paradigm, since then, has become to be known as unsourced multiple access (UMAC) or unsourced random-access (URA). Relevance of the UMAC framework can be attested by its quick recognition in the coding, communication and information theory communities. Indeed, there were two multi-day international workshops held on the topic (at MIT in 2017 and at TUM in 2020), there are dedicated sessions at IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory (ISIT), Asilomar Conference on Signals, Systems, and Comput- ers and International Symposium on Topics in Coding (ISTC). The PI was invited to give plenary talks at Information Theory and Applications (ITA) and at ISTC, as well as a tutorial at ISIT. Very recently, in the summer of 2022, a paper on codes for the UMAC was awarded a prestigious 2022 Communications Society & Information Theory Society Joint Paper Award. Finally, there is a

new emerging technology initiative (ETI) dedicated to the next-generation multiple access (NGMA) that was created by the IEEE Communication Society, with PI as a founding member. The ETI is a first step towards pushing this new technology towards standardization and industry adoption.

Overall, we may conclude that this project?s main outcome is creation of a healthy and active community, unified by a common rigorous framework. Multiple teams (including one lead by the PI) across the globe are now working on the topic and inventing practical random-access coding schemes. As we start to see some initial steps towards industry adoption, we hope that the impact of this (now completed) project will continue to grow in the future.
